bibl.title: Letter from Eduardo Angles to Philip Showalter Hench, August 3, 1940

div1.p: Angles supports the Cuban government's claim for the site of Camp Lazear and rejects the alternative location. He stresses Finlay's preeminence in the yellow fever research. Included is Hench's autograph reaction to Angles' claims.

div1.head: Letter from Eduardo Angles to Philip Showalter Hench, August 3, 1940
div1.opener:
Copy to Moran, Truby, Kean
should it be
Aug 30
Dr Angels 'Memory
is obviously very bad!
PS Hench
Dr. Eduardo Anglés
MEDICO CIRUJANO
----
Teléf. FO-7163
GEN. LEE No. 19. MARIANAO
August 3, 1940
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota.
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
In reference to your letter of August 14, 1940, I have
the honor of answering your first question in which
you mention the fact that you have been asked to make a
report for the Cuban Government explaining why you be-
lieve they have erroneously located the site of Camp
Lazear by the railroad track behind Military City.

I have no doubt whatsoever regarding the veracity of
this point, for I believe that site to be the exact one hav-
ing nothing to do in any way with the Camp established by
Dr. Reed in the San Jose Farm, belonging to Dr. Rojas. This
Camp, very distant from the Military Hospital of Columbia,
was the first established by Dr. Reed before starting to
prove the experiences of Finlay in order to follow the
theories of contagion and the investigations regarding the
“Basilo de Sanarelly”. These investigations failed and
by order of General Wood and Dr. Gorgas, a conference with
Dr. Finlay was decided upon in which, not only did Dr. Finlay
disclose his experiences, give in his works, but proved his
honorability and manliness by turning in the larvae of the
Hestegomia.

Then for these experiences was established the Yellow Fe-
ver Camp, in the place considered by the Cuban Government,
that is behind Military City, then Camp Columbia, past
the Marianao Railroad Track in the “Alturas Farm” of Father
Zamora. After the death of the unfortunate Dr. Lazear, the
25th of September, at which funeral I was present, the
American Government named this Camp, and no other, “Camp
Lazear”. Dr. Jefferson R. Kean, major Doctor of the 7th
Cavalry, who was our chief, was also present at the fu-
neral but not so Dr. Reed who had been staying now for
quite a time in Washington. He did not return to Cuba un-
til after Dr. Lazear and Dr. Agramonte had proven the first
case in the person of the soldier, William D. Dean, from
the 7th Cavalry, news that were cablegrammed by the above
mentioned Doctors to Reed in Washington.

Dr. Eduardo Anglés
MEDICO CIRUJANO
----
Teléf. FO-7163
GEN. LEE No. 19. MARIANAO

You mention the fact that because of the incident in
1900 of having a case of Yellow Fever in Real No. 102
and then another case back of this house, General Lee
No. 20, and still another in front of the latter, Dr.
Reed thought that perhaps a flying insect might be the
transmitter of the Yellow Fever. I have been able to
prove that in Real No. 102, that still under the same
number is the property of Dr. Suarez Solis, existed a
Military office of the American Army but I have been un-
able to prove the case of Yellow Fever to which you make
reference.

In General Lee #20 the proprietor was, and still is,
Major Luis Rodolfo Miranda, at present Sub-Secretary
of State of this Republic. The tenant of this house
does not remember in the last nine years any case of
Yellow Fever. I do remember, however, a case in that
house of a high chief of the American Army reported to
have Yellow Fever by a local Doctor. By order of Major
Kean, Dr. Lazear and myself, after close examination,
came to the conclusion that it was a case of Bronco-
Pneumonia.

In General Lee #16 a case was reported by Dr. Silverio,
a Mrs. Muller; the committee gathered and Dr. Lazear, Dr.
Silverio and myself proved the case to be Yellow Fever.

In the house across the street from this residence Dr.
Kean and his wife suffered a case of Yellow Fever and
were sent to the Yellow Fever Hospital.

I cannot understand how a Dr. as eminent and of such
prestige as Dr. Reed would think that Yellow Fever was
transmitted by a winged agent when in the year 1881,
Dr. Carlos J. Finlay had disclosed his theory proven in a
Congress at Washington, and when Mason's experiences
concerning Filaria O. were already known.

Considerations:-- If Dr. Walter Reed lived he wouldn't
have allowed, because of his honor, to have the glory
of Dr. Finlay be put under consideration for even a moment--
a glory recognized by the whole world.

Dr. Eduardo Anglés
MEDICO CIRUJANO
----
Teléf. FO-7163
GEN. LEE No. 19. MARIANAO

I hope this letter pleases you for such has been my
wish.

If you desire any data in the work you have titled
“Carlos J. Finlay”, in his “Discovery” by Dr. Fran-
cisco Dominguez Roldan, you will surely be able to
find it.
